title: Concept Layers: Enhancing Interpretability and Intervenability via LLM Conceptualization
author: Raphael Bidusa (Technion – Israel Institute of Technology), Shaul Markovitch (Technion – Israel Institute of Technology), ...
relevance_why: The methodology of integrating Concept Layers (CLs) into large language models (LLMs) could enhance interpretability and intervenability in audio-related tasks, aiding in better understanding and refining existing audio models.
background: Improving the transparency and adjustability of large language models to better understand their decision-making processes and mitigate issues like bias.
contribution: This paper introduces Concept Layers (CLs) to enhance existing models' interpretability and intervenability, achieving seamless integration without significant architectural changes.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous models like Concept Bottleneck Models (CBMs) required labeled datasets and significant architectural restructuring.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work allows for automatic concept selection from an ontology and integrates CLs in existing architectures, preserving model performance.

key_innovation: The ability to project internal representations into an interpretable space dynamically while allowing for real-time interventions without extensive retraining.
real_world_impact: The findings could significantly influence fields requiring accountability in model predictions like healthcare, finance, and legal systems by providing tools for bias mitigation.
limitations: The welding process needed for model adaptation introduces a computational cost and depends on the retention of latent representations.

new_terms.Concept Layers: **Concept Layers** are non-trainable modules added to models to project their internal representations into an understandable conceptual space, enhancing both interpretability and user intervention.
new_terms.welding: **Welding** refers to a training phase necessary to adapt existing model parameters to work with newly integrated Concept Layers.
